content:
It is “well known” at least among those who have wondered about this that there is no tricategory whose first three levels are bicategories, (strong) functors, and (op)lax natural transformations, since e.g. there is no way to whisker an (op)lax transformation with a functor.

However, as far as I can tell, this leaves open the possibility that all these components and their “valid” compositions may be faithfully represented in some wider tricategory, e.g. one in which the 1-cells are an appropriate notion of profunctors of bicategories; then, as some profunctors are representables associated with a functor, and these are closed under composition, so some 2-cells between representable profunctors would be representable as (op)lax transformations of functors, and these would be closed under vertical composition but not under horizontal composition and/or whiskering.

To your knowledge, are there any known positive or negative results about the existence of such tricategories?

(A warning: I am interested specifically in n-categorical structures as opposed to multiple categories, so no matter if one thinks that “the correct structure that these form is a triple category” or something, that won't be a helpful answer for me, although you should feel free to share with others!)

Actually it's not whiskering that's the problem, but interchange. You can whisker (op)lax transformations with functors, but in the situation where you'd want to compose two of them horizontally, you get two composites from whiskering and vertical composition, and they aren't isomorphic (only related by a transformation).

At least at first, this seems like it would be an issue for your idea, since if you want the operations on (op)lax transformations that do exist to be respected in your tricategory of profunctors, that would include both vertical composition and whiskering, but then if interchange does hold in your tricategory of profunctors, the inclusion of (op)lax transformations into it couldn't be conservative, which also seems like something you'd want.
Yes, that's right, I got confused for a moment with the issue of lax functors where iirc there is seemingly no way to even define whiskering.

Still it may not be desperate if we don't require whiskering among the operations that we need to respect (at least not in the strongest possible sense).

Looking at the counterexample to horizontal composition of lax transformations on slide 7 of this talk by Bob Paré, I wonder if there might not be a generalisation of lax transformations where "the component at A" is allowed to be a pair of morphisms connected by a 2-morphism --- with "usual" lax transformations being represented as the case where the two morphisms are equal and the 2-morphism is an identity --- so that one is not actually forced to choose between the two "options" presented in that slide.

I am vaguely thinking of something defined in "fibrational" form, so that instead of a "function from nnn-cells to (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-cells” one has “an (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-dimensional fibre over each nnn-cell” which can be relaxed to something higher-dimensional, if maybe “laxly” (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-dimensional, e.g. the higher morphisms “converge” to some terminal (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-morphism...
(I will need some time to think about whether there are obvious issues with this idea)

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

I wonder if there might not be a generalisation of lax transformations where "the component at A" is allowed to be a pair of morphisms connected by a 2-morphism

Of course, then you have to say how to compose two of those horizontally...

Let's work with strict 2-categories and strict functors for simplicity. Let's postulate that a 2-cell between functors F,G:C→DF, G: C \to DF,G:C→D is a pair of lax natural transformations ℓ−,ℓ+\ell^-, \ell^+ℓ−,ℓ+ together with a modification ℓ:ℓ−→ℓ+\ell: \ell^- \to \ell^+ℓ:ℓ−→ℓ+.

It seems to me that there is a good notion of horizontal composition of these: given F,G:C→DF, G: C \to DF,G:C→D and H,K:D→EH, K: D \to EH,K:D→E and 2-cells ℓ:F⇒G\ell: F \Rightarrow Gℓ:F⇒G and m:H⇒Km: H \Rightarrow Km:H⇒K, their horizontal composite m∙ℓ:HF⇒KGm \bullet \ell: HF \Rightarrow KGm∙ℓ:HF⇒KG is the pair of lax natural transformations Kℓ−∘m−F,m+G∘Hℓ+K\ell^- \circ m^-F, m^+ G \circ H\ell^+Kℓ−∘m−F,m+G∘Hℓ+ together with the modification between the two whose component at aaa is either side of this equation:
Screenshot from 2025-01-09 22-16-20.png
(Haven't checked at all what equations this satisfies, just noticing that there does seem to be a "canonical" choice unlike in the case of lax natural transformations.)
Yes, you're right. But I think it won't be a tricategory, since in a tricategory the horizontal composite is still supposed to be isomorphic to both vertical-composites-of-whiskers.

Here's another idea. Modulo some care in making pullbacks strictly functorial, for every nnn there should be a “large strict nnn-category of strict nnn-categories” constructed as follows.
The kkk-cells are pairs of an nnn-category CCC and a strict functor p:C→Okp: C \to O^kp:C→Ok where kkk is the walking kkk-cell. The source/target operations as well as units are obtained by pullback along morphisms in the globe category represented as functors between walking cells. This gives the underlying reflexive nnn-graph (nnn-globular set).
When two kkk-cells are composable at the jjj-boundary, this determines a span of pullback squares of functors; taking its pushout in the arrow category produces an nnn-category over the “walking pasting diagram” Ok#jOkO^k \#_j O^kOk#j​Ok. Pulling back along the “largest kkk-cell” functor Ok→Ok#jOkO^k \to O^k \#_j O^kOk→Ok#j​Ok produces a composite.
Functoriality of pullback does the rest -- the idea is that, with this “colimit then pullback” method, we can extend our nnn-graph to a presheaf on the cell category Θn\Theta_nΘn​ that preserves certain limits by construction, hence defines a strict nnn-category.

When n=1n = 1n=1, I claim that this produces something equivalent to the category of small categories and profunctors. Indeed, O0O^0O0 is the point i.e. terminal category so objects are just small categories, while O1O^1O1 is the walking arrow i.e. the poset (0 < 1), and a functor p:E→O1p: E \to O^1p:E→O1 is the “cograph” representation of a profunctor between the categories in the fibres over the endpoints of the walking arrow.

Given a composable pair p:E→O1p: E \to O^1p:E→O1 and q:F→O1q: F \to O^1q:F→O1, the pushout in the arrow category “glues together” the cographs along the target of the first profunctor and the source of the second, producing a category together with a functor to the “walking composable pair of arrows”, which is equivalently the linear order (0<1<2)(0 < 1 < 2)(0<1<2).
Pulling back along the canonical “endpoint-preserving” functor (0<1)→(0<1<2)(0 < 1) \to (0 < 1 < 2)(0<1)→(0<1<2) gives the cograph of the composite profunctor.

Anyway, when n=2n = 2n=2, this should produce a strict 2-category whose objects are small strict 2-categories.
Now, strict functors seem to be represented as morphisms in the same way as functors are represented as profunctors: namely, if F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D is a strict functor, we get a “cograph” 2-category whose objects are the disjoint union of the objects of CCC and DDD, hom-categories in the two separate components are the same as in CCC and DDD respectively, and the hom-category Hom(c,d)\mathrm{Hom}(c, d)Hom(c,d) for ccc in CCC and ddd in DDD is defined as HomD(Fc,D)\mathrm{Hom}_D(Fc, D)HomD​(Fc,D) (while Hom(d,c)\mathrm{Hom}(d, c)Hom(d,c) is empty).

If I'm not mistaken we can also represent at least oplax transformations between parallel strict functors as 2-cells between their representations: if α:F⇒G\alpha: F \Rightarrow Gα:F⇒G is an oplax natural transformation between F,G:C→DF, G: C \to DF,G:C→D, we define its “cograph” as the 2-category whose

  • objects are the disjoint union of the objects of CCC and DDD,
  • hom-categories in the two components are the same as in CCC and DDD respectively,
  • for c∈Cc \in Cc∈C and d∈Dd \in Dd∈D, the objects of Hom(c,d)\mathrm{Hom}(c, d)Hom(c,d) are the disjoint union of HomD(Fc,D)\mathrm{Hom}_D(Fc, D)HomD​(Fc,D) and HomD(Gc,D)\mathrm{Hom}_D(Gc, D)HomD​(Gc,D),
  • hom-sets in the two separate components of Hom(c,d)\mathrm{Hom}(c, d)Hom(c,d) are as they were,
  • given f:Fc→Df: Fc \to Df:Fc→D and g:Gc→Dg: Gc \to Dg:Gc→D, we let Hom(f,g)=HomD(f,g∘αc)\mathrm{Hom}(f, g) = \mathrm{Hom}_D(f, g\circ \alpha_c)Hom(f,g)=HomD​(f,g∘αc​), while Hom(g,f)\mathrm{Hom}(g, f)Hom(g,f) is empty.

Oplax naturality should ensure that this is well-defined in that the cells and 2-cells of CCC act naturally on Hom(f,g)\mathrm{Hom}(f, g)Hom(f,g): for example, if γ:f⇒g\gamma: f \Rightarrow gγ:f⇒g is a 2-cell between 1-cells f,g:c′→df, g: c' \to df,g:c′→d, and h:c→c′h: c \to c'h:c→c′ is a 1-cell in CCC, the whiskering of γ\gammaγ with hhh is the following 2-cell from fhfhfh to ghghgh:
Screenshot from 2025-01-16 18-44-31.png

So this should give a bona fide 2-category (with strict interchange) where oplax transformations of 2-functors are represented as 2-cells... so either there's a mistake in my reasoning so far, or their horizontal composition or whiskering are genuinely different from the “naive” version; perhaps because of the role of 2-cells of DDD in the “horizontally glued cographs”?

Well, to start with I don't think that "some care in making pullbacks strictly functorial" is going to be sufficient to get out a strict nnn-category. The construction involves not only pullbacks but also pushouts, and even in the two individual cases I don't know of a construction of an nnn-category of "higher (co)spans" that is strict in all dimensions, plus there is the interaction of the two to worry about.

It does seem likely that you'll get a non-strict (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-category at least. But in that case I think your guess at the end is right: the inclusion of oplax transformations into this thing won't preserve their naive horizontal composition.

Yes, the issue of “actual strictness” seems tricky, but then on the other hand, only pullbacks along morphisms in Θ\ThetaΘ and pushouts of nnn-categories that are “displayed over objects of Θ\ThetaΘ” are involved, and maybe that helps; objects of Θ\ThetaΘ are particularly rigid. (It is only a vague sensation, I haven't given much thought to the issues involved.)
When I have the time, I will try to explicitly compute the horizontal composite of two “2-cells represented by oplax transformations”.

Ok, I have now computed the horizontal composite of two 2-cells representing oplax natural transformations, and the result is quite interesting!
I will just give the result for now, I can expand on how one gets to it if anyone's interested.

So let F,G:C→DF, G: C \to DF,G:C→D and H,K:D→EH, K: D \to EH,K:D→E be 2-functors and let α:F⇒G\alpha: F \Rightarrow Gα:F⇒G and β:H⇒K\beta: H \Rightarrow Kβ:H⇒K be oplax natural transformations. There are "cographs" Eα\mathcal{E}_\alphaEα​ and Eβ\mathcal{E}_\betaEβ​ associated to α\alphaα and β\betaβ as I described before: to recall the interesting part,

  • the 1-cells from c∈Cc \in Cc∈C to d∈Dd \in Dd∈D in Eα\mathcal{E}_\alphaEα​ are either f:Fc→df: Fc \to df:Fc→d or g:Gc→dg: Gc \to dg:Gc→d in DDD,
  • the 2-cells from f:Fc→df: Fc \to df:Fc→d to g:Gc→dg: Gc \to dg:Gc→d are 2-cells γ:f⇒gαc\gamma: f \Rightarrow g\alpha_cγ:f⇒gαc​ in DDD

and similarly

  • the 1-cells from d∈Dd \in Dd∈D to e∈Ee \in Ee∈E in Eβ\mathcal{E}_\betaEβ​ are either h:Hd→eh: Hd \to eh:Hd→e or k:Kd→ek: Kd \to ek:Kd→e in EEE,
  • the 2-cells from h:Hd→eh: Hd \to eh:Hd→e to k:Kd→ek: Kd \to ek:Kd→e are 2-cells δ:h⇒kβd\delta: h \Rightarrow k\beta_dδ:h⇒kβd​ in EEE.

Now, the horizontal composite of α\alphaα and β\betaβ in my 2-category is described by a 2-category Eβ∙Eα\mathcal{E}_\beta \bullet \mathcal{E}_\alphaEβ​∙Eα​ over the walking 2-cell O2O^2O2.
The 0-cells of this category are either objects of CCC or objects of EEE. The interesting part is the following.
The 1-cells from c∈Cc \in Cc∈C to e∈Ee \in Ee∈E are, as expected, either h:HFc→eh: HFc \to eh:HFc→e or k:KGc→ek: KGc \to ek:KGc→e in EEE.

But now, a 2-cell from h:HFc→eh: HFc \to eh:HFc→e to k:KGc→ek: KGc \to ek:KGc→e is an equivalence class of 2-cells φ:h⇒k(βGc)(Hαc)\varphi: h \Rightarrow k(\beta_{Gc})(H\alpha_c)φ:h⇒k(βGc​)(Hαc​) in EEE, under the equivalence relation where two 2-cells are identified if and only if their composites with β(αc)\beta(\alpha_c)β(αc​) as in the following diagram
Screenshot from 2025-01-17 17-32-09.png
are equal.

This puts this horizontal composite exactly “in between” the cographs of the two, non-equal, “naive” horizontal composites obtained by whiskering + vertical composition of oplax natural transformations, that is, (βG)(Hα)(\beta G) (H\alpha)(βG)(Hα) and (Kα)(βF)(K\alpha)(\beta F)(Kα)(βF), in the sense that there are 2-functors

E(βG)(Hα)→Eβ∙Eα→E(Kα)(βF)\mathcal{E}_{(\beta G) (H\alpha)} \to \mathcal{E}_\beta \bullet \mathcal{E}_\alpha \to \mathcal{E}_{(K \alpha) (\beta F)}E(βG)(Hα)​→Eβ​∙Eα​→E(Kα)(βF)​

over O2O^2O2...

The first sends φ:h⇒k(βGc)(Hαc)\varphi: h \Rightarrow k(\beta_{Gc})(H\alpha_c)φ:h⇒k(βGc​)(Hαc​) to its equivalence class, whereas the second sends an equivalence class to the composite of each representative with β(αc)\beta(\alpha_c)β(αc​) as in the diagram above, which is by definition independent.
(Presumably this is, in fact, just an epi-mono factorisation of the composite functor of cographs)
Now I would be interested in characterising what is, precisely, the 2-subcategory spanned by oplax natural transformations via this horizontal and vertical composition.
Neat!
(I don't know what "non-actual strictness" would be... aren't things either strict or not?)

Hmm, now I'm thinking that perhaps my description is missing some 2-cells... will have to give it some more thought. It seems to me that if this description were complete, it would imply that this representation is conservative also for "naive whiskerings", which ought to be incompatible with interchange.
